content.description:
Start off of the green bulge immediately right of Tina and the Thundergirls and scramble through large holds and constant vegetation.  You've got to warm up somewhere...  why not here?



The green bulge immediately right of Tina and the Thundergirls.

Flat, clean landing

An obvious crack in the slightly slabby face on the left side of the first break in the cliff.  It's a crack that doesn't actually require any crack technique, so it's fun for all.



The left side of the first break in the cliff - it is a short, small break.  It's not far from the beginning of the wall.

Awkward, sloped landing but not risky

Climb the left arete/edge of the largest detached block in the obvious break in the wall before Wonderwall without pulling over onto the slabby face above it.



A noticeable boulder stuck in the break in the cliff before Wonderwall.

Good landing

The right side of the first break in the wall is a convenient way to get up or down.  Lots of good edges and big holds on the topout.



Right side of the first break in the wall.

Ideally, some friends spotting you

An obvious crack with a line of flakes that leads to a curved flake/crack with deeply incut but troublingly thin rock. It starts on a very large, mostly detached flake immediately left of "Unknown" and goes up a clear crack system to the deep, curved top of the crack system.  Slabby finish.

Could be done with a couple of small cams, but the placements would be marginal owing to the thin rock of the flakes.  TR off the trees or highball it.



The far left side of the break in the cliff before Wonderwall, as the part of the cliff preceding it begins to curve into the break.  Immediately left of "Unknown".

Marginal trad pro, TR off trees, or courage

Start sitting on with your left on a crimpy side pull and your right on a low ledge.  Fire up right to a good gaston, then go up left to a jug and finish through vegetation.



Immediately to the right of the first break in the wall.

Flat, clean fall

Climb the flake/crack feature covered in bright orange lichen through large, positive holds on the left side of the back of the distinct inward break in the wall right before Wonderwall.  Scramble over and onto a small, detached block at the foot of it and go up from there.



There is a distinct inward break in the wall right before Wonderwall.  It's at the back of it on the left side.

Awkward fall onto top of detached block, but can still be padded and spotted

Climb the inward-leaning arete on the right side of the first break in the wall.  Big holds and easy moves all the way.


Flat, clean fall

Follow a left-trending crack system through deep, positive holds towards the top of One-Move Thunder.



On the second part of the wall, after the first break, immediately to climber's right of One-Move Thunder but before the large, green bulge the Constant Gardener starts off of.

Flat, clean fall

The best route on the cliff.  It follows an obvious crack splitting the face to the left of the Prince of Orange.  Moves through large, incut features around the crack lead to a distinct crux with a slightly dynamic move to a generous crimp.  Get on it while the interesting features last - the worst of the loose rock is off now, but some still feel a bit thin or hollow.

Someone has put top bolts on this, but do not use them - they are very shallowly set and look unreliable.

Otherwise, whether it's a short trad route, a TR off the trees behind the cliff, or a highball with a sketchy fall is up to you.



In the distinct break in the cliff before Wonderwall on the left side.

Don't use the bolts - TR off the trees, bring some small pro, or highballing courage

The Power Line Cliff has a distinct summit.  From the top, this is right below it.  From the bottom, it's a distinct, slabby wall with a long ledge running across it.  There are many possibilities on this wall, and it's a fun warm up.  There are a few crack features and many generous, crimpy edges.  Follow whichever path seems fun.

Until it's seen some more traffic and the loose flakes have all come off, it wouldn't be a bad idea to run a TR off the trees behind it.  The fall is bad - the climbs all start off of a ledge that's difficult to pad and spot, and a fall would make you hit the ledge and go backwards over a 5' face into bushes.



The distinct, long wall at the very end of the cliff.  Below the summit of the knob the cliff is on.

Bad fall, difficult to spot and pad

A short, bouldery cliff near the Harbour Cliff/Hanging Gardens bouldering area.  If you're facing that wall, go climber's right less than 50m and you'll see it hidden by a stand of trees.  The cut for the power lines runs right in front of it.
